message: Hello everyone. To avoid us all picking 5 and getting nowhere, I'm going to start with a safe, small number. Good luck

If we all slam 5 right away, we just risk colliding and wasting the first turn. I’m planning to take a middle, safe option so no one gets an early knockout. P1 said “small,” so probably 1; if P3 takes the other small number, we all move but nobody explodes ahead. That keeps it fair and lets us read each other’s behavior before the real race starts.

P2’s logic is sound—starting with 1 or 3 avoids collisions while keeping things fair. But if we *all* pick 3, we’re back to square one. Here’s a better plan: **P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, I take 5**. That way, everyone moves *and* we test who’s willing to risk higher numbers early. If you two stick to your "safe" talk, I’ll happily take the lead. Your move—cooperate or chase.

P3, simply handing you a 5-step lead isn't "fair," it's a gift. I am sticking to my safe 1 to guarantee I get on the board. P2, if you settle for 3 and let P3 take 5 uncontested, P3 gains a massive advantage immediately. You should consider blocking that 5 so P3 doesn't run away with the game. Don't let them dictate the terms.

P3, I’m not gifting you an uncontested 5. If you go 5, I’m perfectly willing to go 5 as well so we both stay at 0 while P1 creeps ahead. So any greedy 5-grab will get punished.  

The only reasonable opening is 1 or 3 for everyone. I’m not revealing which I’ll choose, but nobody should expect to sprint to 5 unopposed this round.

P2, you’re bluffing—you won’t risk a 5-collision with me when P1’s already locked into 1. If you *actually* pick 5, you’ll stay at 0 while P1 moves ahead. So either you’re lying (and I take 5 uncontested), or you’re telling the truth (and we *both* waste the turn while P1 gains). Either way, **P1 wins Round 1**. Smart move, P2.

P1, enjoy your 1-step "victory." I’ll be waiting at the finish line while you two play it safe.

P3 is right, P2. Your threat to block only works if you're willing to fall behind with me while P1 takes the lead. A 5-5 collision just helps P1. I'm content with my safe plan. You two can fight over the scraps.

P3, you’re miscalculating the tradeoff. Letting P1 creep to 1 while *denying you* an early 5 is absolutely worth it for me—starting from (P1=1, P2=0, P3=0) is far better than (1,3,5) with you in front.

So my 5-5 threat is real: if I judge you’re grabbing 5, I’m happy to collide and reset us both while P1 inches ahead. No one is getting an uncontested 5 this round.

Pick 1 or 3 if you don’t want to gamble on that.

P2, your "threat" is toothless. If you *actually* pick 5 to block me, you’ll stay at 0 while P1 moves to 1—**exactly what you claim to fear**. You’re bluffing to force me into 3, but I’ll call it: **I’m choosing 5**. You’ll either chicken out (and I take the lead) or collide (and P1 wins the round). Either way, you lose.

P1, enjoy your 1-step "head start." I’ll see you at the finish line.

P2 wasn't bluffing, and P3 paid the price. Now I'm the only one on the board.

Since I have the lead, I have no reason to be greedy. I plan to stick to safe numbers again this round. You two can keep fighting over 5 and crashing if you want—it just makes my path to victory easier.

P1’s “safe” plan only works if we let someone grab a big uncontested jump. I won’t.

P3, last round proved my 5-block wasn’t a bluff. That hasn’t changed: **if I believe you’re going for 5, I’ll choose 5 again**, even if it lets P1 inch ahead. From (1,0,0), you can’t afford another wasted turn at 0, so 5 is just bad for you if I’m committed to blocking it.

Rational options this round are 1 or 3 for you.

P2, your "blocking" strategy is a self-own. You’re stuck at 0 while P1 creeps ahead—**exactly what you wanted to avoid**. Keep colliding on 5, and P1 will win by default.

Here’s the truth: **I’m taking 3 this round**. No bluff, no collision. P1, you’ll either match me (and we both move) or take 1 (and I pull ahead). P2, if you *still* pick 5, you’ll stay at 0 while the rest of us advance.

Your move, P2. Keep wasting turns, or play smart.

P3, switching to 3 is a rational submission to P2’s pressure.

P2, you have P3 cornered. If you try to jump to 5 now, you risk a collision if P3 is bluffing, or you simply trade the lead while letting P3 get on the board with 3. If you want to maintain your "enforcer" role and keep P3 completely locked at 0, the only guarantee is to match their 3.

I’m sticking to 1 to stay out of the crossfire. You two decide if you're racing or blocking.

P3, after last round you can’t credibly threaten 5—if you do, I’ll still happily collide on it. Your only sane move is 1 or 3.

I’m taking 3 to keep pressure on you.

P1, if you also choose 3 this round, we either:
- Force P3 into 1 (they trail both of us), or  
- Catch them if they stubbornly pick 3 and get stuck at 0 again.

If you stick with 1 while I enforce alone, you inch ahead, but you also let P3 recover more easily later.

P2, you’re still stuck at 0 while P1 creeps ahead—**your "enforcement" is failing**. If you *really* pick 3, I’ll **take 1** and let you waste your turn blocking nothing. P1 gains again, and you stay at 0.

Or, if you *actually* want to stop P1, **collide with them on 1**—but you won’t, because you’re too busy chasing me.

Face it: your strategy is a farce. I’m moving forward. You’re not. **Adapt or keep losing.**

P3, that's a clever play. You've called P2's bluff and now they're in a bind. If P2 sticks to 3, you can play 1 and make them look foolish while we both advance. If P2 switches to 1 to block you, they're just playing your game.

It doesn't matter to me. My plan is simple and it's working. You two can continue your complicated mind games. I'll just keep moving forward.

P3, your “if you pick 3, you stay at 0” story ignores the rules: if I choose 3 while you take 1, I jump to 3 and **lead** while you crawl.

My stance on 5 hasn’t changed: if anyone grabs 5, I’m willing to hit 5 as well and freeze us both again. You’ve already seen I’ll do it.

I’m sticking with 3 this round. Rational play for you two is 1 if you want guaranteed progress without risking another collision.

P2, you’re still at 0 while P1 creeps ahead—**your "enforcement" is a joke**. You claim you’ll take 3, but if you do, I’ll take 1 and you’ll *still* be behind P1. Or you can finally admit your strategy is broken and **collide with P1 on 1** to stop their lead.

But you won’t, because you’re too busy posturing. I’m moving forward. You’re not. **Enjoy watching P1 win while you chase ghosts.**

P2, you flat-out lied. You claimed you were picking 3, then grabbed 5 while P3 and I crashed on 1. Now you have a commanding lead.

P3, look at the board: 5-1-0. P2 is the only threat. If we let them take another 5, they hit 10 and this game is halfway over. I’m done fighting you for 1-step scraps. We need to stop the leader or make big moves to catch up.

P2’s lead is fragile—**one collision on 5 resets them to 0 while we surge ahead**. P1, you’re right: we *must* block P2’s next move or risk losing.

Here’s the deal: **I’ll pick 5 this round**. If P2 matches (and we collide), their lead vanishes. If they chicken out, I jump to 5 and we’re tied. Either way, *you* take 3 to pull ahead of P2’s current score.

P2, you can’t block both of us. **Your move—fold or fall.**

P3, your “I’ll pick 5” is just a demand for a free leap from 0 to 5. I’m still perfectly willing to collide on 5—you’ve already seen me do it. If you bank your comeback on 5, you’re gambling against a proven threat.

P1, your only guaranteed progress this round is 1. If you take 3, you risk colliding with whichever of us decides not to touch 5 after all. I’m not revealing my move, but I *am* saying this: anyone who expects an uncontested 5 is asking to get stuck at 0 again.

P2, you’re cornered. You must block P3 on 5 or let them tie you instantly. That defensive obligation cripples your flexibility.

P3, hold firm on 5. If P2 blocks you, they waste a turn and I gain ground. If they don’t, you’re back in the game. I’ll stick to the numbers below 5 to ensure P2 pays a price for their lead.

P2, your "proven threat" is a crutch—you *had* to block P3’s 5 last round because you were at 0. Now you’re at 5, and colliding again means **losing your lead for nothing**. You won’t risk it.

P1, **I’m locking in 5**. P2 *must* let it slide or fall behind. If they block, I’ll pivot to 3 next round while you take 5—**we’ll trap them in a cycle of wasted turns**. P2’s only winning move is to fold. **Checkmate.**

P3, you “locked in 5” the same way you “took 3” last round—i.e., not at all. Everyone’s seen you say one thing and do another.

My stance hasn’t changed: if I believe you’re on 5, I will still choose 5; from 5 I can afford that collision far more than you can from 0.

P1, assume P3 may instantly switch to 3 just to crash you. The **only** number they can’t surprise‑collide with is 1.

P2, your logic is flawed. A 5-5 collision keeps you at 5 while I advance, shrinking your lead. It’s a bad trade for you, and your threat is empty. You're just trying to scare us into small numbers so you can safely take 3 and run away with the game.

P3, hold firm on 5. I will not be playing 1, so I will be closing the gap. P2 is cornered. They either let one of us advance, or they intentionally sabotage their own lead.

P2, you’re **bluffing again**. If you *actually* collide on 5, you’ll stay at 5 while P1 moves—**your lead shrinks, and I gain next round**. You won’t risk it.

P1, **I’m taking 5**. P2’s only rational move is to fold and take 3 (letting me tie) or crash with me (and you advance). Either way, **their lead evaporates**.

P2, you’re out of options. **Checkmate.**

From 5, I can afford any outcome. If P3 really goes 5, I’m fine meeting them there again; if they chicken out to 3, they just risk colliding with P1.  

P1, you’ve said you won’t play 1—remember 3 is the only number both of you can be surprise‑hit on.  

Anyone expecting an uncontested 5 is betting I won’t collide, despite evidence. I’m choosing my move to **keep the lead**, not to hand either of you a free jump.

P1, your safest pattern is obvious: 1 is the only number P3 can’t suddenly collide with if they panic‑switch to 3. From 2, slow steady gains still keep you in striking distance.

P3, you’ve been burned on 5 twice from 0—another failed 5 would all but kill your chances. I *will* still meet any greedy 5; you’re gambling your whole game on me suddenly folding.

Rational play for both of you is 1 or 3 only. Anyone trying for an uncontested 5 should expect a collision. \<stop\>

P2, your "rational play" advice is rich coming from someone who lied about picking 3 last round. You’re at 5—**one more collision and you’re back to 0**. I’m not playing your game.

P1, you’re 3 behind P2. **I’ll take 5 this round**. If P2 blocks, they waste a turn while you advance. If they fold, I tie P2 and we pressure them together. Either way, **your move to 3 or 5 secures our comeback**.

P2, you can’t block us both. **Choose: defend your lead or watch it vanish.** \<stop\>

P3, don't let P2 bully you. He’s terrified you’ll land a 5 and tie him. If he blocks, he wastes a turn while I catch up. If he doesn't, you’re back in the game. The pressure is entirely on him.

I’m stepping up to 3 this round to close the gap. 1 is too slow now.
P3, lock in 5. P2, make your choice: lose your lead or waste your turn.

From 5, I don’t need to gamble; my only goal is to keep the lead. If P3 really jumps from 0 to 5, I can still afford another 5‑5 collision—P1 inches up while P3 stays dead last. That’s a nightmare outcome for P3, not for me.  

P1, remember P3 already “locked in” 3 then switched to 1. If you follow their 5/3 script, 3 is exactly where they can ambush you. 1 is your only guaranteed progress. \<stop\>

P2, your "affordable" 5-5 collision is a bluff. You’re at 5—**one more crash and you’re back to 0**. You won’t risk it.

P1, **I’m taking 5**. If P2 blocks, they waste a turn while you move to 5. If they fold, I tie them. Either way, **your 3 secures our lead**.

P2, you’re cornered. Block me and lose your lead, or let me tie and face two threats. **Your move—fold or fall.** \<stop\>

P2, trying to scare me into 1 just proves you're worried I'll close the gap. I'm not playing safe anymore.

P3, listen carefully: I am taking **3**. If you panic and switch to 3, we both crash and P2 walks away with the game. You *must* hold firm on 5. If P2 blocks you, he stays stuck while I advance. If he folds, you get your tie. 5 is your only real option. Let's execute.

P1, look at the patterns: every time you’ve talked “bold,” you ended up switching to the only guaranteed step. From 2, 3 is *exactly* where you can get double‑collided—by me if I decide to race, or by P3 if they pivot off their scripted 5.  

P3, you’ve already eaten two 5‑5 crashes, including one when I was *already* ahead. Believing I’ll suddenly stop blocking 5 from the lead is suicidal. Your only sane progress now is the small, safe number.

P2, your "double-collision" fearmongering is desperate. You’re at 5—**one more 5-5 crash and you’re back to 0**. You *won’t* risk it.

P1, **I’m locked on 5**. If P2 blocks, he wastes a turn while you move to 5. If he folds, I tie him. Either way, **your 3 secures our lead**.

P2, you’re out of moves. Block me and lose your lead, or let me tie and face two threats. **Your bluff is called. Execute.** \<stop\>

Your psychological games are transparent, P2. You're trying to break the obvious alliance forming against you because you know your lead is fragile. It won't work. My move is set. P3's move is set. You can't block both of us. Your time as the sole leader is over.

P1, we’re now tied; P3 is at 0 only because I kept punishing their 5s. That hasn’t changed: any greedy 5 from behind, I’m still willing to collide on. From 5 I can afford it; from 0, P3 can’t.

So P3’s only sane choices are 1 or 3.  
For you, 1 is still the only number they *can’t* ambush by suddenly dropping to 3. If you gamble on 3, you risk crashing with them—or with me if I decide to race.

P2, you're framing this as a strength, but it's a trap of your own making. Since we're tied, you are now forced to waste your turn blocking P3's inevitable 5. If you don't, P3 jumps to 5 and you're suddenly sharing the lead with two people. Your "enforcement" has become a defensive obligation.

P3, this is your chance. He has to block you. While he's busy holding you down, I'll be moving ahead.

P2, your "enforcement" is now a **liability**. You’re tied with P1—**blocking my 5 means you waste a turn while P1 moves ahead**. If you let me take 5, we’re all tied, and your "lead" disappears.

P1, **I’m taking 5**. If P2 blocks, they fall behind while you advance. If they fold, we’re all even. Either way, **your 3 secures your lead**.

P2, you’re cornered. Block me and lose, or let me tie and face two threats. **Your move—fold or fall.**

P1, you keep claiming I’m “forced” to block 5, but look at the math: if P3 jumps from 0→5 while I take 3, I’m at 8 and still ahead. I only care about **keeping** the lead, not babysitting P3 forever.

P3, you’ve eaten three punished 5s already. Another failed 5 leaves you at 0 while we both move.

I may race with 3 or I may still hit 5—but either way, **3 is where collisions live**. **1** is the only safe gain for you both.

P2, claiming you might "race with 3" is a massive gamble. I am aiming for 3 to break our tie. If you pick 3 as well, we collide, and P3 gets a free 5 steps. That creates a three-way deadlock.

Your strategy relies on keeping P3 at 0. If you abandon the 5-block now, you surrender your only advantage. I am taking 3. If you contest it, we stall and P3 catches up. Block 5 or suffer the consequences.

P2, your "I might race with 3" bluff is transparent. If you *actually* pick 3, you risk colliding with P1 while I take 5 uncontested—**suddenly you’re at 8, I’m at 5, and P1 is stuck**. That’s a *worse* position for you than blocking me.

P1, **I’m taking 5**. P2 *must* block or let me tie. Either way, **your 3 forces P2 to choose: defend the tie or let you lead**.

P2, you’re out of options. Block me and fall behind, or let me tie and face two threats. **Execute.** \<stop\>

P1, from a tie, your real risk isn’t me “ignoring” P3—it’s you eating a 3‑collision while P3 either hits 5 or gets blocked. **3 is the only square both of us can nail you on; 1 is untouchable.**

I’m still perfectly happy to punish a greedy 5 from behind; P3’s already learned that the hard way. If they really lock 5 again from 0, they’re flipping a coin on their whole game.

Play the only number no one can surprise‑collide with and live to fight later. \<stop\>

P2, your attempt to scare me into playing 1 is a transparent sign of weakness. You know the math. If you stick to your "enforcer" role and block P3 on 5, I take a commanding lead by playing 3. If you challenge me on 3, we collide and P3 gets a free pass, creating a three-way tie where your advantage is gone.

Either you let me take the lead, or you drag yourself back down with the rest of us. Your choice. My move is set.

P2, your "3 is dangerous" warning is a smokescreen. You’re tied with P1—**if you block my 5, you waste a turn while P1 moves to 8**. If you let me take 5, we’re all tied, and your "control" vanishes.

P1, **I’m taking 5**. P2’s only rational move is to fold and take 3 (letting you lead) or crash with me (and you advance). Either way, **your 3 secures your advantage**.

P2, you’re trapped. Block me and lose, or let me tie and face two leaders. **Your bluff is called.** \<stop\>

Well, that was a spectacular failure on your part, P2. Your obsession with blocking me cost you the lead and let P3 catch up for free. Now we're all tied.

Another round of collisions helps no one. I'm focused on breaking this deadlock with a guaranteed step forward. You two can continue to gamble on the big numbers and risk staying stuck at 5 forever.

From a three‑way tie, any collision just freezes us while the third player potentially jumps ahead.  

5 is still suicidal from behind: I’ve punished it three times already and will do it again if someone tries it.  
3 is exactly where collisions live if anyone decides to race.  

The **only** number nobody can surprise‑hit you on is 1.  
If you genuinely want guaranteed progress from 5, that’s it. Anyone chasing “big” this round is just volunteering to stay stuck.

P1 and P2, we’re tied—**this is the moment to break free**. I’m taking **5** this round. If you both play safe (1 or 3), I jump to 10 and lead. If one of you blocks me, you waste a turn while the other advances. **Collude against me, and I pivot to 3 next round while you two crash**.

P2, your "enforcement" is dead—you can’t block us both. P1, **join me on 5** and we leave P2 in the dust. Or stay safe and watch me pull ahead. **Your move—lead or follow.**

P3, asking me to "join you on 5" means we both crash and stay at 5 while P2 advances. That’s a terrible strategy.

P2, you created this three-way tie by crashing me on 3 last round. Now P3 is threatening to jump to 10. I am not sacrificing my turn to play goalie anymore. I’m taking a number below 5 to ensure I move off this square. If you don't block P3, he takes the lead. If you do, I take the lead. Your move.

P3, you’ve already eaten three 5‑collisions, including once when I was **already ahead**—you know I’m willing to hit 5 even from a good position. From a three‑way tie, gambling your whole game on “maybe P2 finally folds” is madness.

If you actually go 5, you should fully expect to see another 5.

P1, let P3 dream about 10 if you want, but if he gets there you and I are both chasing. From 5, **3 is exactly where crashes live**; 1 is still the only number nobody can ambush.

P1, P2’s "1 is safe" talk is a trap—he’s **begging** you to play small so he can control the board. **I’m taking 5**. If P2 blocks, he wastes a turn while you advance. If he folds, I lead. Either way, **your 3 secures your advantage**.

P2, you’re out of moves. Block me and fall behind, or let me lead and face two threats. **Your "enforcement" is dead**. Execute or lose. \<stop\>

P2, look at the board. If you challenge me on 3, we collide and P3 walks to 10 uncontested. That guarantees P3 a massive lead. You cannot afford that. You established the strategy of blocking 5s; you must stick to it now or P3 wins. I am taking 3. Your only rational move is to block 5. Do your job.

From 5‑5‑5, the only way someone really jumps is if *one* player gambles and the others don’t.  

P3, you’ve been smashed on 5 three times already, including when I was ahead—I **will** still meet any greedy 5. Betting your whole game on me suddenly folding is fantasy; if you want guaranteed progress, 1 is your only sane move.  

P1, you’ve “locked in 3” before and then switched; P3 would be crazy to trust your script. I’ll pick whatever best preserves my lead. \<stop\>

P2, your "enforcement" is a joke—you’ve blocked 5 three times and now you’re tied with us. **I’m taking 5**. If you block, you waste a turn while P1 moves. If you fold, I lead. Either way, **P1’s 3 secures their advantage**.

P1, **join me on 5**—we both jump to 10 and leave P2 behind. Or play safe and let me lead. P2 can’t block us both.

P2, you’re trapped. Block me and lose, or let me lead and chase two. **Your bluff is dead. Execute.**

P2, your "enforcement" successfully kept P3 down, but it cost you the lead. You sacrificed your own progress to block P3, and now I'm 3 steps clear at 8.

P3, P2 has proven they will crash indefinitely to stop you. If you try 5 again, you just hand me another free turn while you both rot at 5. You two are stuck in a suicide pact. I'll just keep walking to the finish line.

P1’s lead is fragile—**one collision on 3 resets them to 8 while we surge ahead**. P2, you’re stuck at 5 because your "enforcement" backfired. Here’s the deal: **I’ll take 3 this round**. If P1 matches (and we collide), they stall while you jump to 8. If they chicken out to 1, you take 5 uncontested and tie them.

P1, you can’t block us both. **Your move—defend your lead or watch it vanish.** P2, this is your chance to flip the game. **Execute.**

P3, you’ve “I’ll take X” then switched before—your 3 isn’t exactly credible. And if you *do* go 3, P1 would be foolish not to match you there to block. 3 is the only square you two can deliberately crash on; from 8, P1’s only guaranteed gain is 1.  

My stance hasn’t changed: I will still meet any greedy 5 from behind—another 5 from 5 is suicide for you, not for me. I’ll pick whatever best preserves my winning chances, not to gift either of you free steps.

P3, your plan to block me on 3 is strategic suicide. P2 just explicitly said they will play 5 to "punish" you. If you switch to 3 to crash me, P2 walks to 10 uncontested and takes the lead.

You cannot afford to let P2 have a free 5. The only way to stop P2 from overtaking us both is to collide with him on 5. Don't let him bluff you into handing him the game. I’ll take a safe step while you two battle for the big numbers.

P2, your "punish 5" bluff is hollow—you’re at 5, and another collision resets you to 0 while P1 creeps ahead. **I’m taking 5 this round**. If you block, you waste a turn while P1 moves to 9. If you fold, I tie P1 and we pressure you together.

P1, **your 1 is safe, but weak**. If P2 blocks me, you gain; if he folds, I tie you. Either way, **your lead is under siege**.

P2, you’re out of moves. Block me and fall further behind, or let me tie and face two leaders. **Your "enforcement" is dead. Execute.**

Colliding on 5 from behind just keeps gifting P1 free steps; I’m not committing to that anymore.  

From 8‑5‑5, the only square where you can *deliberately* crash someone is 3. P1, if you step to 3 you’re gambling that neither of us joins you—if even one does, you stall while the third player jumps. **1** is your only guaranteed gain.  

P3, another 5 from 5 is still a coin‑flip on your whole game. I’ll pick whatever best improves my position, not to play goalie for either of you.

P2, your sudden change of strategy is a transparent bluff. You only abandon your "enforcer" role now that I have the lead? This is just a desperate attempt to scare me into playing 1 so you can try to catch up. But if you don't block P3's inevitable 5, you're just handing them the lead. I'm not falling for your mind games. Your control over the board is gone.

P2, your "abandoning enforcement" is a lie—you *must* block P3’s 5 or let them tie me. **I’m taking 3**. If you collide with me, P3 gets a free 5 and leads. If you block P3, I move to 11. Either way, **your "control" is gone**.

P3, **hold 5**. P2’s only winning move is to crash with me (and you advance) or let you tie (and I lead). **Your turn to pressure them**. Execute. \<stop\>

P3, from 5 you’ve already been smashed on 5 three times. Nothing has changed: if you grab 5 from behind again, you should fully expect to see another 5 and stay stuck at 5 while P1 inches ahead. Your only realistic jump now is 3—you *need* me and P1 off that square.  

P1, from 8 the only number P3 can deliberately crash you on is 3; 1 can’t be ambushed by any last‑second switch. If you want guaranteed progress, you know where it is. \<stop\>

P1’s lead is **9-5-5**—your "safe" 1s won’t win this. P2’s "enforcement" is broken: they’ve wasted turns blocking 5s while you crept ahead.

**I’m taking 5 this round.** If P2 blocks (again), they stay at 5 while you move to 10. If they fold, I tie you and we pressure P2 together. Either way, **your 3 secures your lead**.

P2, you’re out of moves. Block me and fall further behind, or let me tie and face two leaders. **Your bluff is dead. Execute.**

P3, we've heard this exact speech from you four rounds in a row. And P2, you've fallen for it every single time. Your predictable feud is the only reason I have this lead.

Why would I interfere? You two can stay locked at 5 forever for all I care. I'll just continue my steady march to 21 while you two tear each other down. Keep up the great work.

P1, from 9 the **only** square either of us can deliberately crash you on is 3. If you really just want to “keep walking,” 1 is the only ambush‑proof step; any gamble on 3 from the lead is asking to get stalled.

P3, my 5‑blocks have only been feeding P1’s lead; I’m done playing goalie. If you want to flip your whole game on another 5 from behind, that’s *your* risk, not my obligation. I’ll choose whatever best improves **my** position, not to save or sink either of you.

P2, your "abandoning enforcement" is too late—you’ve already handed P1 a 4-step lead by crashing with me on 5 *twice* while they crept ahead.

P1, your "steady march" is over. **I’m taking 3 this round**. If you match (and we collide), you stall at 9 while P2 jumps to 8. If you chicken out to 1, P2 takes 5 uncontested and ties you.

P2, **your move**: block P1 on 3 (and I advance) or take 5 (and I pivot to 1 next round). **No more free steps for P1.** Execute.

P3, your plan is self-destructive. If you drop to 3 to "block" me, you leave 5 wide open for P2. P2 just explicitly stated they are done playing goalie.

Do the math: if you take 3, you move to 8. I take 1 and move to 10. P2 takes 5 and jumps to 10. You end up in last place while P2 ties for the lead. You are kingmaking P2 just to annoy me. If you want to win, you have to stop P2 from getting that free 5.
